awd_titl_txt: Student Support for International Requirements Engineering Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports student travel for U.S. students to attend the 26th International Requirements Engineering Conference to be held in Banff, Alberta, Canada from August 24th -28th, 2018. This is the flagship conference in this subfield of Software Engineering, where research and practice comes together. The purpose is to advance and grow this field of research. Students will meet senior researchers and colleagues to exchange ideas and collaborate to advance the field. Doctoral students will attend the Doctoral Symposium where they will receive feedback on their research. The grant will contribute to building an a globally aware workforce of scientists and engineers. The field of Requirements Engineering works toward improving the quality of software-intensive systems as well as the productivity of the processes that produce them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Requirements drive many aspects of the Software Development life cycle such as architecture and design, testing, safety analysis, runtime adaptation, and change management. There are many open challenges which need to be addressed in order to deliver fully-functioning, safe, secure, scalable, and reliable software systems, and it is therefore very important to engage the next generation of researchers. The IEEE International Requirements Engineering Conference is the premier international forum for researchers, industrial practitioners, educators, and students to present and discuss the most recent innovations, trends, experiences, results and challenges in the field of requirements engineering.

This grant provided funds for six graduate students from US Institutions to attend the IEEE Requirements Engineering conference. Two of the funded students were first year PhD students with plans to work in the Requirements Engineering space.  The remaining four students were at various stages of their dissertations, focusing on topics related to security requirements, automated requirements validation, and using machine learning to extract requirements from App reviews. Attending the conference provided exposure to cutting edge research ideas and open challenges in the field of Requirements Engineering.  This exposure can potentially shape the future direction of the students' research and is influential in building the next generation of Requirements Engineering researchers. 

Attending the conference was beneficial to all six students and enabled them to better understand the critical open challenges in Requirements Engineering research.


Last Modified: 08/04/2019
Modified by: Jane L Huang
